title.rendered: How to Avoid Tax Fraud Scams in 2025

content.rendered:
Tax fraud scams continue to evolve, becoming more sophisticated each year. In 2025, scammers are leveraging new technologies, including artificial intelligence and social media, to deceive taxpayers. The consequences of falling victim to tax fraud can be severe, ranging from identity theft to financial loss and legal complications. Understanding how these scams operate and taking proactive steps to safeguard personal and financial information is essential for all taxpayers. By staying informed, taxpayers can recognize red flags, protect themselves from fraudulent schemes, and know what to do if they become victims of a tax fraud scam.

Common Tax Fraud Scams in 2025 

As scams become increasingly complex, taxpayers must be aware of the latest fraudulent schemes targeting their personal and financial information. 

Impersonation Scams (Emails, Texts, and Phone Calls) 

One of the most prevalent tax fraud tactics involves impersonation scams. Fraudsters pose as IRS agents, using phishing emails, fraudulent text messages, and phone calls to trick individuals into providing sensitive personal and financial information. These scams often employ official-looking IRS logos, professional language, and caller ID spoofing to appear legitimate. 

For example, a taxpayer might receive an email claiming to be from the IRS, stating that there is an urgent issue with their tax return. The email may include a link directing the recipient to a fake IRS website where they are asked to enter their Social Security number and bank details. In another scenario, a scammer might call a taxpayer, claiming that they owe back taxes and must make an immediate payment via gift card or cryptocurrency to avoid legal consequences. 

Fake Tax Preparers 

Many taxpayers rely on professional tax preparers to navigate the complexities of filing their returns. Unfortunately, not all tax preparers operate ethically. Some fraudulent preparers file false returns without the taxpayer’s knowledge, steal refunds, or charge excessive fees for their services. 

A common scheme involves a preparer inflating deductions or falsely claiming credits to generate a larger refund, which they then divert to their own accounts. In some cases, fraudulent preparers file returns in the names of unsuspecting individuals, only for the taxpayers to discover later that a return has already been submitted under their Social Security number. 

Social Media and AI-Generated Scams 

With the rise of artificial intelligence technology, scammers have developed new methods to deceive taxpayers. Social media platforms are frequently used to impersonate IRS officials, tax professionals, or financial advisors, spreading misinformation and tricking individuals into sharing personal data. 

One emerging scam involves AI-generated voice calls that mimic the voices of IRS representatives, instructing taxpayers to verify their identity by providing sensitive information. Another tactic involves fake advertisements for tax relief programs that lead victims to fraudulent websites designed to harvest personal details. 

Phony Tax Credits 

Scammers often exploit taxpayers by promoting fraudulent tax credits that either do not exist or do not apply to the claimant. Two common examples in 2025 include the false fuel tax credit and the bogus self-employment tax credit. 

The fuel tax credit is intended for off-highway business use, such as for farming equipment, but fraudsters encourage ineligible taxpayers to claim it. Similarly, scammers falsely suggest that self-employed individuals can claim tax credits that do not legally apply to their income status, leading to audits and penalties. 

Fake Charities 

Natural disasters and humanitarian crises often create opportunities for scammers to exploit generous taxpayers. Fraudsters set up fake charities that appear to support disaster relief efforts, using deceptive websites and marketing campaigns to solicit donations. Taxpayers who contribute to these illegitimate organizations may later find that their donations are not tax-deductible and that their personal information has been compromised. To avoid falling for these scams, taxpayers should verify the legitimacy of charities through the IRS Tax Exempt Organization Search Tool before making donations. 

How to Protect Yourself 

Taking proactive steps to safeguard personal information can help taxpayers prevent tax fraud and financial loss. 

  1. Verify IRS Communications: When receiving unexpected correspondence from the IRS, taxpayers should verify its authenticity by contacting the agency directly through official channels.  
  1. Use Trusted Tax Professionals: Hiring a reputable tax professional can significantly reduce the risk of fraud. Taxpayers should choose preparers who have a valid PTIN, are registered with the IRS, and have a history of ethical practice.  
  1. Monitor Your Tax Records: Setting up an IRS Online Account allows taxpayers to monitor their tax records and detect any suspicious activity.  
  1. File Early: Filing tax returns as early as possible reduces the window of opportunity for scammers to submit fraudulent claims. 
  1. Use Strong Cybersecurity Practices: Taxpayers should enable multi-factor authentication on their online accounts, use secure passwords and an IP PIN, and 

 avoid accessing sensitive information on public Wi-Fi networks.  

What to Do If You’re a Victim 

Knowing how to respond quickly after falling victim to tax fraud can help mitigate damage and restore financial security. 

Report the Fraud to the IRS 

Victims of tax fraud should immediately report the incident to the IRS using Form 14039 (Identity Theft Affidavit). This form notifies the IRS of the fraudulent activity and initiates the process of securing the taxpayer’s records. 

Contact the Federal Trade Commission and Credit Bureaus 

In cases of identity theft, taxpayers should also report the fraud to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) through their online complaint system. Contacting credit bureaus—Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion—allows victims to place fraud alerts on their credit reports, preventing further misuse of their personal information. 

Place a Fraud Alert or Credit Freeze 

A fraud alert notifies creditors to take extra steps in verifying a taxpayer’s identity before issuing new credit. In more severe cases, a credit freeze can prevent any new accounts from being opened under the taxpayer’s name, offering additional protection. 

Tax Help for Victims of Tax Fraud Scams 

Avoiding tax scams in 2025 is all about staying alert and protecting your personal information. Scammers are getting clever, so it’s important to recognize warning signs like unexpected calls, texts, or emails asking for money. Always double-check anything that seems off—remember, the IRS will never reach out to you via text or email. Stay safe by using secure methods to communicate, and if something feels fishy, don’t hesitate to report it. Affordable Tax Relief is the nation’s leading tax resolution firm with over a decade of experience helping taxpayers with tough tax situations.  

If You Need Tax Help, Contact Us Today for a Free Consultation
